title: statsreportr
text: can install development version statsreportr GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("KyleOfCanada/statsreportr")

title: statsreportr
text: examples functions statsreportr. examples outputing R console, intended used inline R Markdown Quarto document. used inline code R Markdown Quarto document, following inline code: results t test showed significant difference mpg 6 (`r mtcars |> report_mean_sd(mpg, cyl, effect = "6")`) vs 8 (`r mtcars |> report_mean_sd(mpg, cyl, effect = "8")`) cylinder cars (`r report_t(results4, effect = c("6", "8"), cohensd = cohensd4, cohens_magnitude = TRUE)`). render : results t test showed significant difference mpg 6 (19.7 ± 1.45) vs 8 (15.1 ± 2.56) cylinder cars (t(18.5) = 5.29, adjusted p < 0.0001, d = 2.23, indicating large effect).
code: library(statsreportr)  # ANOVAs results <- mtcars |>   rstatix::anova_test(mpg ~ cyl)  format_p(results$p) #> [1] "< 0.0001"  results2 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::anova_test(mpg ~ cyl * carb)  results3 <- aov(mpg ~ cyl * carb, data = mtcars)  report_anova(results2) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 47.2, *p* < 0.0001, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.628" report_anova(results2, "carb") #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 1.55, *p* = 0.223, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.052" report_anova(results2, 2) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 1.55, *p* = 0.223, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.052" report_anova(results3, 2) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 1.55, *p* = 0.223, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.052"  # t-tests results3 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::t_test(mpg ~ am)  report_t(results3) #> [1] "*t*~(18.3)~ = -3.77, *p* = 0.00137"  results4 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::t_test(mpg ~ cyl)  cohensd4 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::cohens_d(mpg ~ cyl)  report_t(results4,   effect = c("6", "8"),   cohensd = cohensd4, cohens_magnitude = TRUE ) #> [1] "*t*~(18.5)~ = 5.29, adjusted *p* < 0.0001, *d* = 2.23, indicating a large effect"  # Descriptive stats  mtcars |> report_mean_sd(mpg, cyl, effect = "6") #> [1] "19.7 ± 1.45"  mtcars |> report_mean_sem(mpg, cyl, effect = "6") #> [1] "19.7 ± 0.549"

title: statsreportr
text: following functions available package: format_p(): Format p-values readable. report_mean_sd(): Report mean standard deviation variable. report_mean_sem(): Report mean standard error mean variable. report_anova(): Report results ANOVA test. report_t(): Report results t-test. report_pc(): Report results pairwise comparisons test. cor_test(): Conduct correlation test. report_cor(): Report results correlation test.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kyle Roddick. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Roddick KM (2025). statsreportr: Easy stats reports inline. R package development.
code: @Manual{,   title = {{statsreportr: Easy stats reports inline}},   author = {Kyle M Roddick},   year = {2025},   note = {R package in development}, }

what: Report Formated Statistical Tests In Rmd or qmd Documents
title: Report Formated Statistical Tests In Rmd or qmd Documents
text: goal statsreportr make easy report results statistical analyses inline code R Markdown Quarto document.

title: Report Formated Statistical Tests In Rmd or qmd Documents
text: can install development version statsreportr GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("KyleOfCanada/statsreportr")

title: Report Formated Statistical Tests In Rmd or qmd Documents
text: basic examples shows generate reports ANOVAs t-tests: intent package used inline R Markdown Quarto document. example, following inline code: results t test showed significant difference mpg 6 (`r mtcars |> report_mean_sd(mpg, cyl, effect = "6")`) vs 8 (`r mtcars |> report_mean_sd(mpg, cyl, effect = "8")`) cylinder cars (`r report_t(results4, effect = c("6", "8"), cohensd = cohensd4, cohens_magnitude = TRUE)`). render : results t test showed significant difference mpg 6 (19.7 ± 1.45) vs 8 (15.1 ± 2.56) cylinder cars (t(18.5) = 5.29, adjusted p < 0.0001, d = 2.23, indicating large effect).
code: library(statsreportr)  # ANOVAs results <- mtcars |>   rstatix::anova_test(mpg ~ cyl)  format_p(results$p) #> [1] "< 0.0001"  results2 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::anova_test(mpg ~ cyl * carb)  results3 <- aov(mpg ~ cyl * carb, data = mtcars)  report_anova(results2) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 47.2, *p* < 0.0001, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.628" report_anova(results2, "carb") #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 1.55, *p* = 0.223, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.052" report_anova(results2, 2) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 1.55, *p* = 0.223, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.052" report_anova(results3, 2) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 1.55, *p* = 0.223, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.052"  # t-tests results3 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::t_test(mpg ~ am)  report_t(results3) #> [1] "*t*~(18.3)~ = -3.77, *p* = 0.00137"  results4 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::t_test(mpg ~ cyl)  cohensd4 <- mtcars |>   rstatix::cohens_d(mpg ~ cyl)  report_t(results4,   effect = c("6", "8"),   cohensd = cohensd4, cohens_magnitude = TRUE ) #> [1] "*t*~(18.5)~ = 5.29, adjusted *p* < 0.0001, *d* = 2.23, indicating a large effect"  # Descriptive stats  mtcars |> report_mean_sd(mpg, cyl, effect = "6") #> [1] "19.7 ± 1.45"  mtcars |> report_mean_sem(mpg, cyl, effect = "6") #> [1] "19.7 ± 0.549"

title: Correlation Test — cor_test
text: Provides pipe-friendly framework perform correlation test paired samples, using Pearson, Kendall Spearman method. Wrapper around function cor.test(). Can also performs multiple pairwise correlation analyses two variables two different vectors variables. Using function, can also compute, example, correlation one variable vs many. slight modification cor_test package rstatix. Saves degrees freedom Pearson correlation output.

title: Correlation Test — cor_test
code: cor_test(   data,   ...,   vars = NULL,   vars2 = NULL,   alternative = "two.sided",   method = "pearson",   conf.level = 0.95,   use = "pairwise.complete.obs" )

title: Correlation Test — cor_test
text: data data.frame containing variables. ... One unquoted expressions (variable names) separated commas. Used select variable interest. Alternative argument vars. vars optional character vector containing variable names correlation analysis. Ignored dot vars specified. vars NULL, multiple pairwise correlation tests performed variables data. vars contain one variable, pairwise correlation analysis performed specified variable vs either remaining numeric variables data variables vars2 (specified). vars contain two variables: ) vars2 specified, pairwise correlation analysis performed possible combinations variables. ii) vars2 specified, element vars tested elements vars2 . Accept unquoted variable names: c(var1, var2). vars2 optional character vector. specified, element vars tested elements vars2. Accept unquoted variable names: c(var1, var2). alternative indicates alternative hypothesis must     one "two.sided", "greater" "less".      can specify just initial letter.  "greater" corresponds     positive association, "less" negative association. method character string indicating correlation     coefficient  used test.  One "pearson",     "kendall", "spearman", can abbreviated. conf.level confidence level returned confidence     interval.  Currently used Pearson product moment     correlation coefficient least 4 complete pairs     observations. use optional character string giving     method computing covariances presence     missing values.  must (abbreviation ) one strings     "everything", ".obs", "complete.obs",     "na..complete", "pairwise.complete.obs".

title: Correlation Test — cor_test
text: return data frame following columns: var1, var2: variables used correlation test. cor: correlation coefficient. statistic: Test statistic used compute p-value. p: p-value. conf.low,conf.high: Lower upper bounds confidence interval. method: method used compute statistic.

title: Correlation Test — cor_test
text: cor_test(): correlation test two variables.

title: Correlation Test — cor_test
code: # Correlation between the specified variable vs # the remaining numeric variables in the data #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: mtcars |> cor_test(mpg) #> # A tibble: 10 × 9 #>    var1  var2    cor statistic    df        p conf.low conf.high method  #>    <chr> <chr> <dbl>     <dbl> <int>    <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>   #>  1 mpg   cyl   -0.85     -8.92    30 6.11e-10  -0.926     -0.716 Pearson #>  2 mpg   disp  -0.85     -8.75    30 9.38e-10  -0.923     -0.708 Pearson #>  3 mpg   hp    -0.78     -6.74    30 1.79e- 7  -0.885     -0.586 Pearson #>  4 mpg   drat   0.68      5.10    30 1.78e- 5   0.436      0.832 Pearson #>  5 mpg   wt    -0.87     -9.56    30 1.29e-10  -0.934     -0.744 Pearson #>  6 mpg   qsec   0.42      2.53    30 1.71e- 2   0.0820     0.670 Pearson #>  7 mpg   vs     0.66      4.86    30 3.42e- 5   0.410      0.822 Pearson #>  8 mpg   am     0.6       4.11    30 2.85e- 4   0.318      0.784 Pearson #>  9 mpg   gear   0.48      3.00    30 5.4 e- 3   0.158      0.710 Pearson #> 10 mpg   carb  -0.55     -3.62    30 1.08e- 3  -0.755     -0.250 Pearson  # Correlation test between two variables #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: mtcars |> cor_test(wt, mpg) #> # A tibble: 1 × 9 #>   var1  var2    cor statistic    df        p conf.low conf.high method  #>   <chr> <chr> <dbl>     <dbl> <int>    <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>   #> 1 wt    mpg   -0.87     -9.56    30 1.29e-10   -0.934    -0.744 Pearson  # Pairwise correlation between multiple variables #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: mtcars |> cor_test(wt, mpg, disp) #> # A tibble: 9 × 9 #>   var1  var2    cor    statistic    df         p conf.low conf.high method  #>   <chr> <chr> <dbl>        <dbl> <int>     <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>   #> 1 wt    wt     1    367570386.      30 2.27e-236    1         1     Pearson #> 2 wt    mpg   -0.87        -9.56    30 1.29e- 10   -0.934    -0.744 Pearson #> 3 wt    disp   0.89        10.6     30 1.22e- 11    0.781     0.944 Pearson #> 4 mpg   wt    -0.87        -9.56    30 1.29e- 10   -0.934    -0.744 Pearson #> 5 mpg   mpg    1          Inf       30 0            1         1     Pearson #> 6 mpg   disp  -0.85        -8.75    30 9.38e- 10   -0.923    -0.708 Pearson #> 7 disp  wt     0.89        10.6     30 1.22e- 11    0.781     0.944 Pearson #> 8 disp  mpg   -0.85        -8.75    30 9.38e- 10   -0.923    -0.708 Pearson #> 9 disp  disp   1          Inf       30 0            1         1     Pearson  # Grouped data #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: iris |>   dplyr::group_by(Species) |>   cor_test(Sepal.Width, Sepal.Length) #> # A tibble: 3 × 10 #>   Species   var1  var2    cor statistic    df        p conf.low conf.high method #>   <fct>     <chr> <chr> <dbl>     <dbl> <int>    <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>  #> 1 setosa    Sepa… Sepa…  0.74      7.68    48 6.71e-10    0.585     0.846 Pears… #> 2 versicol… Sepa… Sepa…  0.53      4.28    48 8.77e- 5    0.290     0.702 Pears… #> 3 virginica Sepa… Sepa…  0.46      3.56    48 8.43e- 4    0.205     0.653 Pears…  # Multiple correlation test #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: # Correlation between one variable vs many mtcars |> cor_test(   vars = "mpg",   vars2 = c("disp", "hp", "drat")  ) #> # A tibble: 3 × 9 #>   var1  var2    cor statistic    df        p conf.low conf.high method  #>   <chr> <chr> <dbl>     <dbl> <int>    <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>   #> 1 mpg   disp  -0.85     -8.75    30 9.38e-10   -0.923    -0.708 Pearson #> 2 mpg   hp    -0.78     -6.74    30 1.79e- 7   -0.885    -0.586 Pearson #> 3 mpg   drat   0.68      5.10    30 1.78e- 5    0.436     0.832 Pearson  # Correlation between two vectors of variables # Each element in vars is tested against all elements in vars2 mtcars |> cor_test(   vars = c("mpg", "wt"),   vars2 = c("disp", "hp", "drat")  ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   var1  var2    cor statistic    df        p conf.low conf.high method  #>   <chr> <chr> <dbl>     <dbl> <int>    <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>   #> 1 mpg   disp  -0.85     -8.75    30 9.38e-10   -0.923    -0.708 Pearson #> 2 mpg   hp    -0.78     -6.74    30 1.79e- 7   -0.885    -0.586 Pearson #> 3 mpg   drat   0.68      5.10    30 1.78e- 5    0.436     0.832 Pearson #> 4 wt    disp   0.89     10.6     30 1.22e-11    0.781     0.944 Pearson #> 5 wt    hp     0.66      4.80    30 4.15e- 5    0.403     0.819 Pearson #> 6 wt    drat  -0.71     -5.56    30 4.78e- 6   -0.850    -0.484 Pearson

what: Format a p value for presentation in a R Markdown or Quarto document — format_p
title: Format a p value for presentation in a R Markdown or Quarto document — format_p
text: Format p value presentation R Markdown Quarto document

title: Format a p value for presentation in a R Markdown or Quarto document — format_p
code: format_p(p_value, digits = 3)

title: Format a p value for presentation in a R Markdown or Quarto document — format_p
text: p_value p value format digits number digits round p value

title: Format a p value for presentation in a R Markdown or Quarto document — format_p
text: string formatted p value

title: Format a p value for presentation in a R Markdown or Quarto document — format_p

what: Report an ANOVA result in text — report_anova
title: Report an ANOVA result in text — report_anova
text: Report ANOVA result text

title: Report an ANOVA result in text — report_anova
code: report_anova(ANOVA, effect = 1, digits = 3)

title: Report an ANOVA result in text — report_anova
text: ANOVA rstatix::anova_test object stats::aov object effect name row number Effect report digits number digits round p value

title: Report an ANOVA result in text — report_anova
text: string formatted ANOVA result use inline R Markdown Quarto document

title: Report an ANOVA result in text — report_anova
code: library(rstatix) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘rstatix’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:statsreportr’: #>  #>     cor_test #> The following object is masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter  results <- anova_test(mtcars, mpg ~ cyl * carb)  report_anova(results) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 47.2, *p* < 0.0001, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.628" report_anova(results, effect = "cyl") #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 47.2, *p* < 0.0001, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.628" report_anova(results, effect = 2) #> [1] "*F*~(1,28)~ = 1.55, *p* = 0.223, $\\eta^2_G$ = 0.052"

what: Report correlation result in text — report_cor
title: Report correlation result in text — report_cor
text: Report correlation result text

title: Report correlation result in text — report_cor
code: report_cor(cor_test, effect = 1, digits = 3)

title: Report correlation result in text — report_cor
text: cor_test rstatix::cor_test object effect names row number Effect report digits number digits round p value

title: Report correlation result in text — report_cor
text: string formatted correlation result use inline R Markdown Quarto document

title: Report correlation result in text — report_cor
code: library(rstatix)  results <- mtcars |> cor_test(mpg, wt) report_cor(results) #> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `df`. #> [1] "*r*~()~ = -0.87, *p* < 0.0001"  results2 <- mtcars |>  group_by(cyl) |>  cor_test(mpg, wt, method = "spearman")  report_cor(results2, effect = 2) #> [1] "$\\rho$ = -0.65, *S* = 92.7, *p* = 0.111"  results3 <- mtcars %>% cor_test(     vars = "mpg",     vars2 = c("disp", "hp", "drat"),     method = "kendall"   )   report_cor(results3, effect = c("mpg", "disp")) #> [1] "*$\\tau$* = -0.77, *T* = -6.11, *p* < 0.0001"

what: Report the mean and standard deviation in text — report_mean_sd
title: Report the mean and standard deviation in text — report_mean_sd
text: Report mean standard deviation text

title: Report the mean and standard deviation in text — report_mean_sd
code: report_mean_sd(.data, value_var, group_var = NULL, effect = 1, digits = 3)

title: Report the mean and standard deviation in text — report_mean_sd
text: .data data frame value_var name variable report group_var name grouping variable effect name row number effect report digits number digits round p value

title: Report the mean and standard deviation in text — report_mean_sd
text: string mean standard deviation variable format: "mean ± sd"

title: Report the mean and standard deviation in text — report_mean_sd
code: mtcars |> report_mean_sd(value_var = mpg) #> [1] "20.1 ± 6.03" mtcars |> report_mean_sd(mpg, cyl, effect = "6") #> [1] "19.7 ± 1.45"

title: Report the mean and standard error of the mean in text — report_mean_sem
text: Report mean standard error mean text

code: report_mean_sem(.data, value_var, group_var = NULL, effect = 1, digits = 3)

title: Report the mean and standard error of the mean in text — report_mean_sem
text: .data data frame value_var name variable report group_var name grouping variable effect name row number effect report digits number digits round p value

title: Report the mean and standard error of the mean in text — report_mean_sem
text: string mean standard error variable format: "mean ± sem"

title: Report the mean and standard error of the mean in text — report_mean_sem
code: mtcars |> report_mean_sem(value_var = mpg) #> [1] "20.1 ± 1.07" mtcars |> report_mean_sem(mpg, cyl, effect = "6") #> [1] "19.7 ± 0.549"

what: Report a pairwise comparison result in text — report_pc
title: Report a pairwise comparison result in text — report_pc
text: Report pairwise comparison result text

title: Report a pairwise comparison result in text — report_pc
code: report_pc(pairwise_comparison, effect = 1, digits = 3, effect_size = TRUE)

title: Report a pairwise comparison result in text — report_pc
text: pairwise_comparison rstatix::emmeans_test object effect names row number effect report digits number digits round p value effect_size Whether include effect size report

title: Report a pairwise comparison result in text — report_pc
text: string formatted pairwise comparison result use inline R Markdown Quarto document

title: Report a pairwise comparison result in text — report_pc
code: library(rstatix)  results <- emmeans_test(mtcars, mpg ~ am)  report_pc(results) #> [1] "*t*~(30)~ = -4.11, adjusted *p* < 0.001, *d* = -1.48"  results2 <- emmeans_test(mtcars, mpg ~ cyl, p.adjust.method = "none")  report_pc(results2, effect = 3) #> [1] "*t*~(29)~ = 3.11, *p* = 0.00415, *d* = 2.05"  report_pc(results2, effect = c("4", "6")) #> [1] "*t*~(29)~ = 4.44, *p* < 0.001, *d* = 1.88"

what: Report a t test result in text — report_t
title: Report a t test result in text — report_t
text: Report t test result text

title: Report a t test result in text — report_t
code: report_t(   ttest,   effect = 1,   digits = 3,   cohensd = NULL,   cohens_magnitude = FALSE )

title: Report a t test result in text — report_t
text: ttest rstatix::t_test object effect names row number effect report digits number digits round p value cohensd rstatix::cohens_d object include effect size report cohens_magnitude logical indicating effect size magnitude included report

title: Report a t test result in text — report_t
text: string formatted t test result use inline R Markdown Quarto document

title: Report a t test result in text — report_t
code: library(rstatix)  results <- t_test(mtcars, mpg ~ am)  report_t(results) #> [1] "*t*~(18.3)~ = -3.77, *p* = 0.00137"  results2 <- t_test(mtcars, mpg ~ cyl)  cohensd2 <- cohens_d(mtcars, mpg ~ cyl)  report_t(results2, cohensd = cohensd2, cohens_magnitude = TRUE) #> [1] "*t*~(13)~ = 4.72, adjusted *p* < 0.001, *d* = 2.07, indicating a large effect"  report_t(results2, effect = c("4", "6")) #> [1] "*t*~(13)~ = 4.72, adjusted *p* < 0.001"

title: statsreportr 0.0.0.9005
text: report_pc() fixed bug data selection effect size calculation.

title: statsreportr 0.0.0.9004
text: report_pc() now able report effect sizes pairwise comparisons. effect size calculated using emmeans::eff_size() function.

title: statsreportr 0.0.0.9003
text: cor_test() report_cor() added package. functions used report results correlation tests. cor_test() modified version rstatix::cor_test() save degrees freedom Pearson correlation output, report_cor() formats results reporting R Markdown Quarto documents.

title: statsreportr 0.0.0.9002
text: report_pc() added package. function used report results pairwise comparison test. designed used conjunction function emmeans_test() ‘rstatix’ R package, used inline r code within R Markdown Quarto documents.

title: statsreportr 0.0.0.9001
text: report_mean_sd() report_mean_sem() added package. functions used report mean standard deviation standard error dataset, respectively. designed used inline r code within R Markdown Quarto documents.

title: statsreportr 0.0.0.9000
text: report_anova() report_t() added package. functions used report results ANOVA t-tests, respectively. designed used conjunction functions anova_test() t_test() ‘rstatix’ R package, used inline r code within R Markdown Quarto documents. report_anova() also works aov() objects running rstatix::anova_summary() object reporting results. format_p() added package. function used format p-values report-ready format. mainly used format p-values within report_*() functions, available use contexts well.
